articles.headline: How United Airlines Is Trying to Plan Around a Pandemic
articles.snippet: The airline has to figure out which planes to stash in the desert and which ones to park at airports without knowing when demand will recover.
articles.abstract: The airline has to figure out which planes to stash in the desert and which ones to park at airports without knowing when demand will recover.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus pandemic wiped out travel in the spring, United Airlines slashed its flight schedule, salted away aircraft in the New Mexico desert and parked planes at hangars around the country.

articles.headline: Unemployment Claims Rise Anew in Latest Sign of Economic Distress
articles.snippet: Hopes for a rebound of the American economy have been clouded by layoffs, a surge in virus cases and a lack of fresh federal aid.
articles.abstract: Hopes for a rebound of the American economy have been clouded by layoffs, a surge in virus cases and a lack of fresh federal aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy is showing fresh signs of deceleration, hammered by layoffs, a surge in coronavirus cases and the lack of fresh aid from Washington.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Gillian Friedman

articles.headline: Twitter Changes Course After Republicans Claim ‘Election Interference’
articles.snippet: It had blocked an unsubstantiated New York Post article about the Bidens but said late Thursday that it would allow similar content to be shared.
articles.abstract: It had blocked an unsubstantiated New York Post article about the Bidens but said late Thursday that it would allow similar content to be shared.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — President Trump called Facebook and Twitter “terrible” and “a monster” and said he would go after them. Senators Ted Cruz and Marsha Blackburn said they would subpoena the chief executives of the companies for their actions. And on Fox News, prominent conservative hosts blasted the social media platforms as “monopolies” and accused them of “censorship” and election interference.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Kate Conger

articles.headline: Facebook and Twitter Dodge a 2016 Repeat, and Ignite a 2020 Firestorm
articles.snippet: The companies have said they would do more to stop misinformation and hacked materials from spreading. This is what that effort looks like.
articles.abstract: The companies have said they would do more to stop misinformation and hacked materials from spreading. This is what that effort looks like.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since 2016, when Russian hackers and WikiLeaks injected stolen emails from the Hillary Clinton campaign into the closing weeks of the presidential race, politicians and pundits have called on tech companies to do more to fight the threat of foreign interference.

articles.headline: When Armed Vigilantes Are Summoned With a Few Keystrokes
articles.snippet: Kevin Mathewson, who quickly organized the Kenosha Guard on Facebook, said the Wisconsin city’s police were outnumbered during protests. The streets turned deadly after his call to arms.
articles.abstract: Kevin Mathewson, who quickly organized the Kenosha Guard on Facebook, said the Wisconsin city’s police were outnumbered during protests. The streets turned deadly after his call to arms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tapping on his cellphone with a sense of purpose, Kevin Mathewson, a former wedding photographer and onetime city alderman in Kenosha, Wis., did not slow down to fix his typos as he dashed off an online appeal to his neighbors. It was time, he wrote on Facebook in late August, to “take up arms to defend out City tonight from the evil thugs.”

articles.headline: ‘I Just Kind of Lost It’: As Coronavirus Cases Soar, One Montana Town Reels
articles.snippet: In the Mountain West, an outbreak has revealed the danger that the virus poses to jails and rural communities.
articles.abstract: In the Mountain West, an outbreak has revealed the danger that the virus poses to jails and rural communities.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREAT FALLS, Mont. — For months, the jail in central Montana’s Cascade County was free of the coronavirus, which seemed as distant a threat as it did in much of the nation’s rural Mountain West.
articles.byline: By Lucy Tompkins, Maura Turcotte and Libby Seline

articles.headline: Before Nov. 3, Watch This and This and This
articles.snippet: A number of movies, documentaries and TV mini-series that are coming out have immediate relevance to the 2020 election.
articles.abstract: A number of movies, documentaries and TV mini-series that are coming out have immediate relevance to the 2020 election.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeff Daniels agreed to play James Comey in Showtime’s “The Comey Rule” on the promise that the four-hour mini-series would be released ahead of the election. The documentary filmmaker Alex Gibney worked at a breakneck pace to complete his feature-length film “Totally Under Control,” an indictment of the Trump administration’s handling of the coronavirus, so it could debut before Nov. 3.

articles.headline: ‘It’s Fall! Here We Are!’ A Beloved Chocolate Shop Returns
articles.snippet: Lee Sims in Jersey City made it through the shutdown thanks to ingenuity and customer loyalty. It’s back just in time for the busiest season.
articles.abstract: Lee Sims in Jersey City made it through the shutdown thanks to ingenuity and customer loyalty. It’s back just in time for the busiest season.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY, N.J. — Valerie Vlahakis, the owner of Lee Sims Chocolates, a mom-and-pop shop between a florist and a pharmacy on a scruffy block in Jersey City’s McGinley Square, eyed ghosts in her display window as she waited for patrons to return.
